citation.article-title: Thermobacteroides acetoethylicus gen. nov. and spec. nov., a new chemoorganotrophic, anaerobic, thermophilic bacterium.

p.s: Description of Thermobacteroides acetoethylicus sp. nov.
Thermobacteroides acetoethylicus (A. ce. to. e. thy. licus. L. n. acetum vinegar. M. L. n. ethylicus ethyl alcohol)
Morphology.
Rods 0.6 by 1.5-2.5 μm.
Single or paired cells, motile by peritrichous flagellation, Gram-negative, and endospores not formed.
Colonies are uniformly round, mucoid, nonpigmented, flat, and grow to a diameter of 3 mm in 48 h.
Cellular Characteristics.
DNA base composition of 31 (±1) mol% G + C content.
Cytochrome pigments and catalase not detectable.
Multiple-layered cell wall architecture without an outer wall membrane.
Temperature and pH Relationships.
Optimum temperature for growth 65°C, maximum <80°C and minimum >40°C.
pH range for growth is between 5.5 and 8.5.
Physiology.
Chemoorganotroph.
Utilizes a variety of saccharides as energy sources including glucose, mannose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, sucrose, and starch.
Obligate anaerobe.
Growth inhibited by air, NaCl (2%), tetracycline, streptomycin, penicillin G, vankomycin, and neomycin.
Major fermentation end products in glucose-complex medium include ethanol, acetate, isobutyrate, butyrate, hydrogen and carbon dioxide, but not lactate.
Thiosulfate, but not sulfate, reduced to sulfide.
Embden-Meyerhof glycolytic pathway.
Habitat.
Thermal environments associated with the anaerobic decomposition of photosynthetic biomass.
Type Strain.
HTB 2.

This strain was isolated from Octopus Spring sediment located in Yellowstone National Park, U.S.A., and has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, Md.), ATCC acquisition number 33265.
